Beginner.<a href='https://docs.python.org/3/tutor: The official, free tutorial is recommended if you have some programming experience, but you are new to python itself. It will give you a brief overview of the language, but won't go too deep into details.
Beginner.<a href='http://www.diveintopython3.net/: Are you an experienced programmer but new to python? Do you dislike the official tutorial? In that case this free book is the go-to recommendation for you.
This book will teach you the basics of python programming. You'll be able to write small programs that will automate tedius everyday tasks. The book is free and also has a video-course (first half is free on youtube). No prior programming experience required.

Intermediate.<a href='http://www.amazon.com/Fluent-Py: Once you understand the basics of python, you should understand its idioms and best practices. The first half of the book will introduce you python's data structures, with internal implementation details. The 2nd half goes into more depth with iterators, generators, coroutines and even metaprogramming.
Intermediate.<a href='http://www.amazon.com/Python-Co: As the name suggests it's a general cookbook that also covers more advanced recipes and highlights features from python3. Altho we suggest you read the book, because it's great, the receips are available for free on Beazley's github page

GENERAL.<a href='https://'www.codeupstart.com/'>: "Learn to code by creating real startups"
